summary:
With 7+ years in health/science industries, I am a mission-driven, innovation-inspired strategic senior leader in the intersecting space between population health, scientific research and technology. My systems-based approach brought about by a broad, global background, combined with my passion for people-centric leadership, has paved the way for a rewarding journey in solving biotechnology's most pressing and interesting challenges. 

Skilled in program/project/people management, data-driven process optimization/continuous improvement, Agile/LEAN, strategic alignment/deployment & culture-building, AI analytics, scientific research, design thinking, and product commercialization/GTM strategy. 

I believe in the power of diversity of thought to solve problems, and enjoy advocating for & mentoring women interested in leadership/STEM. In my personal time, you can find me distance running, spending time in the mountains, or listening to podcasts.

Websites: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Dana-Jessen-Howard / www.womeninbio.org/member/danajessenhoward

Collaborate with me: danakjessenhoward@gmail.com

currentPositions.description:
Data-driven strategy management for existing product lines and new product/platform launches in the consumer innovation division to improve population health access and science translation, communication and education to the public.

Managing other people managers including the leadership team/ops managers of scientists/scientific researchers, nutritionists/clinicians, PM roles, and science/product experts.
 
 Our multidisciplinary team works on some of the toughest unmet  medical needs for which microbes can become or replace the primary standard of care.

Seed Health is a carbon-negative microbial sciences biotechnology and research company pioneering applications in human health & therapeutics and in the recovery and biodiversity of ecosystems impacted by human activity. Using a One Health approach, we maintain a core nucleus of research, development, and commercialization infrastructure to scale up numerous programs in parallel, enabling rapid, efficient translation of breakthrough research across a diverse set of microbial applications.
currentPositions.title: SciCare Manager

fieldsOfStudy: Medical Biotechnology, (Bio/)Technology in Science/Health Spaces, Business Innovation

publications.description:
I was a first author in this work. 

Human aldehyde dehydrogenases (ALDHs) comprising 19 isoenzymes play a vital role in both endogenous and exogenous aldehyde metabolism. This NAD(P)-dependent catalytic process relies on the intact structural and functional activity of the cofactor binding, substrate interaction, and the oligomerization of ALDHs. Disruptions on the activity of ALDHs, however, could result in the accumulation of cytotoxic aldehydes, which have been linked with a wide range of diseases, including both cancers as well as neurological and developmental disorders. In our previous works, we have successfully characterised the structure–function relationships of the missense variants of other proteins. We therefore applied a similar analysis pipeline to identify potential molecular drivers of pathogenic ALDH missense mutations. Variants data were first carefully curated and labelled as cancer-risk, non-cancer diseases, and benign. We then leveraged various computational biophysical methods to describe the changes caused by missense mutations, informing a bias of detrimental mutations with destabilising effects. Cooperating with these insights, several machine learning approaches were further utilised to investigate the combination of features, revealing the necessity of the conservation of ALDHs. Our work aims to provide important biological perspectives on pathogenic consequences of missense mutations of ALDHs, which could be invaluable resources in the development of cancer treatment.
publications.name: Identifying the Molecular Drivers of Pathogenic Aldehyde Dehydrogenase Missense Mutations in Cancer and Non-Cancer Diseases

publications.description:
I interned in this work.

Neurodegenerative disorders affect around one billion people worldwide. They can arise from a combination of genomic, epigenomic, metabolic, and environmental factors. Aging is the leading risk factor for most chronic illnesses of old age, including Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. A progressive neurodegenerative process and neuroinflammation occur, and no current therapies can prevent, slow, or halt disease progression. To date, no novel disease-modifying therapies have been shown to provide significant benefit for patients who suffer from these devastating disorders. Therefore, early diagnosis and the discovery of new targets and novel therapies are of upmost importance. Neurodegenerative diseases, like in other age-related disorders, the progression of pathology begins many years before the onset of symptoms. Many efforts in this field have led to the conclusion that exits some similar events among these diseases that can explain why the aging brain is so vulnerable to suffer neurodegenerative diseases. This article reviews the current knowledge about these diseases by summarizing the most common features of major neurodegenerative disorders, their causes and consequences, and the proposed novel therapeutic approaches.
publications.name: Novel Approaches for the Treatment of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s Disease

message.text:
I’m hiring!

Looking for someone who:
✔️ Has a scientific background, including scientific research, literature evaluation and dissemination, and science writing
✔️ Excels in communicating science to the public in a way that inspires and intrigues
✔️ Thrives in fast-paced environments, loves to learn, and is excited to launch into new horizons of growth on a mission to serve human + planetary health

This role will be fully remote, and include independent work as well as team and cross-functional collaboration.

Apply here: https://lnkd.in/gZiJEwwp

As a former bioinformatician… this might be the current innovation happening at Seed Health that I’m most excited about. Truly incredible work by this team. 

Check it out!

🌱A Milestone Moment for Seed Health and the Future of the Microbiome 🌱

Today marks a monumental day in our journey—reflecting years of work and a deep belief in the transformative power of the microbiome. From our inception, we've been driven by a singular vision: to unlock the microbiome’s vast potential for human and planetary health. 

Now, we’re excited to introduce CODA 🚀, our latest leap forward, propelled by the groundbreaking work of renowned computational biologist and microbiome pioneer Professor Eran Segal and The Human Phenotype Project. 

CODA is our computational biology platform, leveraging the world's most comprehensive host-microbiome dataset. It comprises over 3 million observable data points collected across 13,000 individuals and spanning 40,000 subject years. The dataset captures the diversity of human health factors—including biological, environmental, and dietary influences, lifestyles, and medical histories—at unparalleled depth and scale, uncovering new insight into the role of the microbiome in human health and disease. 

The translation of microbiome science has long been challenged by complexity and variability. With CODA, we address these issues head-on, using AI, machine learning, and microbial genomics to enable the precise identification of reliable patterns and correlations between the microbiome and various health outcomes for the first time. 

With this new clarity, we can develop precision probiotics and microbiome-directed interventions to target critical health outcomes including metabolic health, brain function, menopause, and longevity. More soon. 👀

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/epV-3Qt9

I had the recent honor of an invitation to speak with the Business Leadership Program at the University of Puget Sound. 

I shared
• my personal journey with leadership,
• the benefits of career pivots,
• the importance of diversity on teams,
• and the business case for women in executive roles, in every industry. 

It was a privilege to meet so many students eager to make a difference. Thank you for having me Alan Krause!

Interested in sharing your extensive career experience to help biotech executives? eMAPS is a great way to help your community and empower others’ success. Applications due in 10 days!

Apply now to become an #ExecutiveCoach for the #WIBSeattle Executive Mentorship Program (eMAPS)! Complete the Google Form: https://lnkd.in/gY6imXRU

Our eMAPS programs offer professional development for emerging executives in life sciences. Learn more about the eMAPS program here: https://lnkd.in/guSe_GPu We seek an Executive Coach to play a crucial role in this program by guiding and mentoring our participants toward their professional development goals.

Location: Must be willing to attend monthly in-person meetings in the Greater Seattle area.

Duration: The duration of this engagement will be up to a year and a half, coinciding with the annual cycle of the eMAPS program and its enrollment period before the launch of the cohort.

Key Responsibilities:
◾Facilitate discussions among mentees and the other executive life science mentors. Coach and guide the mentees in setting clear goals for their career advancement and personal development. Share insights, best practices, and advice from personal experience.
◾Ensure a culture of support, sharing, confidentiality, and professionalism is consistently maintained throughout the program.
◾Actively share lessons learned, resources, and best practices across the eMAPS program, fostering a collaborative learning environment.
◾Enhance the eMAPS executive mentoring program with a positive and enthusiastic environment that fosters enjoyment for all participants.
◾Work closely with the eMAPS leadership team to prepare for monthly mentorship meetings.
◾Set the eMAPS syllabus and contribute to developing and updating materials and resources.
◾Identify potential guest speakers who can share valuable insights and perspectives.
◾Review application materials for the eMAPS cohort and interview potential eMAPS candidates.

Attendance Commitment: Commit to attend launch and 80% of eMAPS program in-person meetings (approximately 10 of 12 meetings).

Time Commitment:
Monthly:
◾2 hours attending eMAPS recurring monthly in-person meetings
◾1-3 hours preparing eMAPS meeting materials and prework
◾1-2 hours on eMAPS program communications
Quarterly:
◾1-hour mentor planning and check-in meeting
At launch:
◾2-4 hours interview/discuss candidates

Qualifications:
◾Proven experience as an executive coach with a track record of mentoring and supporting individuals in reaching their professional goals.
◾Excellent interpersonal and communication skills.
◾A commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion in the workplace.
◾Willingness to travel to Seattle for monthly in-person meetings.
◾Understanding the biotech and life sciences industries is a plus.

Payment: The exact compensation details for this role will be communicated separately and will not be included in this scope of work.

Complete the Google Form: https://lnkd.in/gY6imXRU
Please send any questions to seattleemaps@womeninbio.org at eMAPS Seattle. Apply by March 17.

commentary.text: Could not be more proud to work at Seed Health than I am today 🌱

Always in awe of you, Rachel!
